He is doubtless making his way to the enemy.
The above reward will be given for his restorstion to me.

div3.head: 500 Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber on the 10th of March last, my negro man Peyton.
He is about 5 feet 10 inches high, 25 years of age, black, large feet and hands, with prominent lips and eyes Has, I think, a mark on his left arm, above the from disease.
I will give a reward of $300 if taken in the county of Albemarte, or the above amount if caught out of said county, and placed in some jail where.
I can secure him again.
div3.closer:
A. P. Giles,
Scottsville, Albemarie co, Va. ap 30--d2w

div3.p: To the Friends of the Soldiers throughout the Confederacy.--

div4.head:
Quartermaster Gent'ts Department,
railroad Bureau,
Richmond, Feb. 20, 1864.
div4.p: The friends and relatives of soldiers in the Army of Northern Virginia are hereby notified that an arrangement has this day been effected with the Southern Express Company to carry all packages of food and wearing apparel to Richmond, Va.
To secure the advantages thus obtained through the Express Company, the following instroctions must be observed:

Packages must not contain more than one hundred pounds; be well secured and plainly marked, and sent at the expense of the shipper to either of the Soldiers Relief Associations, which are located as follows:
In North Carolina, at Releigh; in South Carolina, at Columbia; in Georgia at Augusta; in Alabama at Montgomery; or to any other point at which one of these Association have an office.

To Agents of these Associations will there take charge of them and ship daily by South in Express Company to the proper Agents of the respective States at Richmond, who will see them distributed to the proper individual owners.

To meet the wishes of the soldiers, and to give them, the Southern Express Company has agreed to give this eight preference over everything else; and, in order that no obstacle may occur to the seccess of so laudable an enterprise, the several railroad companies are hereby requested to render the Express Company such facilities as will enable it to make this arrangement a complete success.

As the Southern Express Company assumes all responsibility of the transportation of these pack ages, the Relief Associations are requested to with draw their Agents who have heretofore acted as travelling messengers.
If the Relief Associations will establish agencies in the rear of other ar they may enjoy the same privileges hereby secured to the Army of Northern Virginia.
div4.closer:
F. W. Sims,
Lieut-Col. and Quartermaster.
Approved: A. R. Lawton,
Quartermaster General

div4.head:
Office Southern Express Company
Augusta, Ga, Feb. 20, 1864.
div4.p: The Southern Express Company hereby notify the friends and relatives of soldiers in the Army of parel to carry out arrangements as announced in the above card, and that they will do all in their power to fulfill its requirements.
div4.closer:
James Shuter,
General Sup't and Acting President,
Southern Express Company. fe 27--m

div3.p:
To Maryland man in the Confederate Service.--It is believed that General Orders No. 35.
Adjutant and inspector General officer just published, all the which have heretofore interprised to to prompt invasions to the Maryland Line.
Every person now in service who was at the begining of the war a service or adopted citizens of Maryland can, upon application to Major General , Staunton, Virginia, Colonel Bradley T. Johnson, Hanover Junction, Virginia, be immediately transferred to the Maryland Line.
The following form can be signed, to before a commissioned officer, directed to the above officers, and send by mail, when the transfer will be immediately made.
The applicant state if he wishes to be transferred to Major General , Camp Maryland, Stauton, Virginia, or Colonel Bradley T. Johnson, Camp Howard, Hanover junction, and to a company already to form a new company.
Applications for cavalry must be accompanied by efficient that applicant can keep himself mounted.

Johnson, Hanover Junction.
Appended is proof of

On this — day of--, the subscriber, a commissioned officer, --Regiment,--Brigade, --, and made oath in due form law, that he knows that-- -- was a citizen of Maryland at the commencement of the war, and that he is keep himself .
All applicantion to be transferred to Camp Maryland will, for the present, he addressed to Major General Arnold Richmond, Virginia.
